headers: REFERENCE VSL BREAKDOWN — DR. GINA SAM / EMMA RELIEF

rows.REFERENCE VSL BREAKDOWN — DR. GINA SAM /: Anatomy of the Emma Relief VSL mapped to our 12-block structure

rows.col_2: "7 Second Morning Ritual" — curiosity gap + simplicity promise. Doctor authority from frame one.
rows.col_3: Specific, intriguing, promises easy solution. Doctor = instant credibility.
rows.col_4: Need equivalent: "[X]-second pre-workout ritual" or "the one electrolyte ingredient your body is missing"

rows.col_2: Gut bacteria, methane gas, bloating, constipation. Uses medical terminology + graphics to make it visceral.
rows.col_3: Makes invisible problem visible. Viewer suddenly understands WHY they feel bad.
rows.col_4: Chronic dehydration, electrolyte imbalance, why plain water isn’t enough. Make invisible problem visible.

rows.col_2: "Probiotics don’t work because they don’t address methane-producing archaea." Disqualifies every competitor.
rows.col_3: Positions all alternatives as incomplete. Only Emma addresses the real cause.
rows.col_4: "Sports drinks are 30g of sugar. Electrolyte packets are underdosed. Water alone doesn’t replace what you lose."

rows.col_2: Years of research led to discovery of root cause. Transition from hopeless to hopeful.
rows.col_3: Doctor narrative creates journey. Viewer goes from "nothing works" to "maybe this is different."
rows.col_4: Authority figure’s personal discovery. "After years of seeing athletes cramping despite hydrating..."

rows.col_2: Targets methane-producing bacteria specifically. Explains berberine, star anise, quercetin. Science-heavy.
rows.col_3: Unique mechanism = reason to believe. Not just "our ingredients are better" but "here’s WHY it works differently."
rows.col_4: Sodium-potassium pump mechanism. Why ratio matters. Why most products get the ratio wrong. Peer-reviewed studies.

rows.col_2: Emma Relief capsules. Clean packaging. "Doctor-formulated." Shows the bottle.
rows.col_3: Simple reveal after mechanism is understood. Product feels like logical conclusion.
rows.col_4: IonWave reveal. Clean label, clinical dosing, zero sugar. "This is what I now recommend to my patients/athletes."

rows.col_2: Customer testimonials. Before/after stories. "650,000+ customers." Trustpilot 4.6/5 rating.
rows.col_3: Volume of proof. Specific numbers. Named people.
rows.col_4: Beta tester testimonials. Athlete endorsements. Specific results ("eliminated cramps in 3 days").

rows.col_2: Multi-bottle tiers: 1 bottle, 3 bottles, 6 bottles. Increasing discount per bottle. Free bonuses at higher tiers.
rows.col_3: Tiered pricing makes 3-bottle feel like best value. Bonuses add perceived value without cost.
rows.col_4: Same: 1/3/6 bottle tiers. Subscription option at each. Digital bonuses (hydration guide, workout recovery protocol).

rows.col_2: "A single doctor visit costs $200+. A month of Emma is less than $1.60/day."
rows.col_3: Reframes price against expensive alternatives and daily cost.
rows.col_4: "Less than your daily coffee. A fraction of what you spend on sports drinks that don’t work."

rows.col_2: 90-day 100% satisfaction guarantee. "You have nothing to lose."
rows.col_3: Removes final objection. Makes purchase feel risk-free.
rows.col_4: Same: 90-day guarantee. "If you don’t feel the difference, full refund, no questions."

rows.col_2: "Click the button below to get your supply of Emma." Clear, specific, repeated.
rows.col_3: Simple, direct. Repeated multiple times in closing section.
rows.col_4: Same: "Click below to get IonWave. Choose your package." Repeated 3x.

rows.col_2: "Limited supply." "This offer may not be available tomorrow."
rows.col_4: Launch pricing, limited first batch, or seasonal urgency. Must be genuine.
